element_texts.text: Completed

[in upper right corner in pencil, in handwriting not SA's: "K C 1933"]
Mr. Pendergast.

    I am here, with a committee of women who are making a study of the problems of working women + girls, in K C M + K C K. We are sent here for this study by the Nat Board of the Y M C A. What we are trying to do, by our study, is to find a [?] [?] which we can make [?] accommodating to the local organization that will make it [?] on any
Completed

2.
women yield more affection.

    As your question ll Mr P the purpose of the Y M C A is in many possible way to make a bit more with the [?] of [?] in the same few industrial would. The [?], in any work, to be any practical + direct as possible and I know you have had wide experience. I would like an interview with you to get for me what ideas you have that might help. I will come to you at your convenience.

    Sincerely,
Completed

2
might go. Do you mean to say that you  would want me to go to some other house  with the book of the play. I myself believe that the play as written is bound to be rather first rate dramatic literature.

    And I do think in general Mr Perkins that you should not be too decided. I think I should feel free to come to you from time to time and talk of plans as to a friend.  I have a certain conception of what I conceive to be the right relationship between a writer and his publisher, a relationship that might be,at its best a kind of intellectual marriage and in any such relationship I do not think  that either side should be too positive.

   I say all of this with no intention of trying to get you to publish anything of mine ahead of the sort of more important things you speak of . . . . with the possible exception of the play but rather to put down a kind of general feeling I have and that I think should at once be made as clear as possible. I am very sure you will agree with me

    Sincerely


P.S. As I am about of copies will you esteem the [?] of the Winesburg play as soon as you have had a chance to read it.
Completed

[letterhead: The Marion Publishing Company, Marion, VA]
Dear Max Perkins.

    These are the articles I thought of making into a book.

    The other articles I will send later.

    Sherwood Anderson
Completed

[in upper right corner, in blue ink in a hand not SA's, "Oct 1934"]
Dear Max - 

    Mrs A told me of the conversation with you. I am sending the enclosed as a kind of finish for the book.

    I am rather sorry that you did not think [?][?] thing - an [?] newspaper-fellow; for the book.

    Would the other things with the one ending be enough?

    Sherwood Anderson

Gramercy 7-4373
Completed

[Letterhead: The Hollenden, Cleveland, OH]
Dear Max Perkins - 

    I have your letter, forwarded to me from ["Chicago" lined out by SA] Virginia. Am in Chicago. There is one and possibly two new things I think might be added to the book. I will ask Stewart, of Today to send
Completed

[letterhead: The Hollenden, Cleveland, OH]
2
over a sketch of young Holt - the new boy senator from West Virginia and there is a thing I submitted to Scribner's Magazine. Don't know whether or not they'll use it. I think it also could be nice in the
Completed

[letterhead: The Hollenden, Cleveland, OH]
3
book. Ask them to let you see it.

    Today wants to get into touch with you. Did they see you. This was your notion of their pushing the book, in your kind of circulation scheme.

    Am not broke
Completed

[letterhead: The Hollenden, Cleveland, OH]
4
now Max, so never mind the advance. I'll [squeal?] if I need some money.

    I'll get right back into the introduction and hope I may hit on a good title.

    Sincerely

    Sherwood Anderson
Completed

[letterhead: Leland Hotel, Springfield, IL]
Max Perkins

    "Puzzled Americans."

    "We Want To Believe"

    Here are two title suggestions for the book. Have written the introduction and sent it home for fair copy. You should have it in a few days.

    I rather like - "We Want To Believe" for the title.

    Have rewritten [Bill?]
Completed

[letterhead: Leland Hotel, Springfield, IL]
2.
Stewart of Today to send you over the Salt article.
I made a slight change in the manuscript about copyright. Am sure you won't mind putting it in my name.

    Made the suggestion about play rights etc, because a play [maker?] in [?] of a play forwarded an
Completed

[letterhead: Leland Hotel, Springfield, IL]
3
Blue [?]
Sincerely
Sherwood Anderson
Completed

[letterhead: Ripshin Farm, Troutdale, Virginia]
Dear Max Perkins,

    I am afraid my letters got mixed up. I wrote a first one that got left in the car and [?] mailed until I had written a second.

    They will however straighten themselves out.

    I like the title - 
       Puzzled America

rather than puzzled Americans.

    Sincerely

    Sherwood Anderson
Completed

[letterhead: Ripshin Farm, Troutdale, Virginia. In upper right corner in blue ink, in handwriting not SA's, "Jan. 1935 / over" is written]

         Corpus Christi Tex.

Dear Max Perkins

    I came down here, [driving?] with Mrs A by car - stopping at New Orleans, [2 words illegible] until to day. Now a bitter cold wind is blowing from the North. We will leave here in a few days ad go on down to Brownsville Texas. We are temporarily here, in a little house by the Gulf.

    I have at last got into a novel, a queer but, to me, very moving book that may come off. I'll let
Completed

[letterhead: Ripshin Farm, Troutdale, Virginia]
2
you know how it comes along.

    Of course am anxious to know what you decide about including the other articles in Puzzled Americans, and to see the [?] in proofs.

    I want to dedicate the book to my friend, Roger Sergel.

    Sincerely

    Sherwood Anderson
Completed

[letterhead: Hotel Mario, Ocala, FL]

         Sunday

Dear Max Perkins

    I am up against it for books. The half dozen author's copies does not take care of those I have to give away. Send me another half dozen, addressed to me % Mrs B E Copenhaver, Marion Va and charge to me.

    I get such grand letters about the book, I hope they'll buy it.

    I expect to be back here a week from today and then come east. The farm looks grand. You'll have to come down here this summer.

    As Always
         Sherwood Anderson

Also will you send copy of the book to [Ben?] and Louisa [?] - to the Dutch steamer Statendam - sailing April 30. Charge to me.
Completed

[in upper right corner, in blue ink in.handwriting not SA's, "May 1935" is written]
Dear Max,

    Shouldn't I have the trade discount on the April 26th bill also.

   Sincerely
   Sherwood Anderson
Completed

[in upper right corner, in handwriting not SA's, "Sept. 1935" is written]
[letterhead: Ripshin Farm, Troutdale, Virginia]
Dear Max Perkins.

    I entrained to N Y yesterday bur came up into the country at once. I am staying with Mr. Burton Emmett, at Valley Cottage N.Y. but will be down soon. I got through the novel - first writing . . . and hope to get right back at it for revisions.

    Gave [?] [?] some new work I'd like to talk over with you soon.

    Sincerely
    Sherwood Anderson
Completed

2.
Make into a book in the spring.

    Am going for a day with Ham Basso next week. Mrs Anderson said she wrote you about coming down to see our place sometime this summer. I hope you will.

    I shall be expecting the proof sheets to Kit anytime now.

    Sincerely
    Sherwood Anderson

Will be at Trout Dale Va until October - 

    I appreciate the books you occasionally send me.

    Just now there is a kind of [flame?] for my stories, etc, in England. They are being published in magazines over there and also sindicated in newspapers. Do you have any connections in London that might be interested in doing Kit Brandon. Curtis Brown is my London agent.

If you come down will take you over to see the T.V.A.
Completed

[letterhead: The George Vanderbilt Hotel, Asheville, NC]

    Tuesday

Dear Max Perkins.

    Am going down for a day with Ham Basso. [?] and evening in Asheville an will spend part of today here.

    Tell Dashiell I have a hunch to do an article I might call Tom Wolfe's Town - a theory I have, that some subtile change takes place in a town after a fellow like Wolfe
Completed

[letterhead: The George Vanderbilt Hotel, Asheville, NC]
2
lives and works in it.

    Any, if I do the piece, it should be fine.

    Sincerely
    Sherwood Anderson
